Basic Level FAQs – Employees 
1. What is POSH? 
 
POSH stands for ‘Prevention of Sexual Harassment’. This is the short form of a law that was 
enacted after the ‘Nirbhaya’ incident of December 2012. The full name of the law is – 
Prevention of Sexual Harassment of Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 
2013. The objective of the Act is to protect women from sexual harassment in any workplace.

This law mandates that any office or workplace or place of business that has more than 10 
employees must have an Internal Committee to address any complaint of sexual harassment. 
The law also defines “sexual harassment” and “workplace”. 
 
2. Why is it important to train employees? Why am I taking this training? Why is the training of 
employees mandated by POSH law? 
 
Employees are expected to know about the POSH Act so that they ensure that their workplace

interactions, behaviours and words do not create an unsafe or hostile working environment 
for anyone around them. They must ensure that they are behaving professionally in all work-
related contexts or situations. Employees are also provided training so that they know the 
correct complaint mechanism and process. You can find your Internal Committee or POSH 
Committee details in your company’s POSH policy.  
 
3. Who is covered by the POSH law? Who is covered under POSH Act?

All employees of an organisation are covered by POSH Act. But “employee” doesn’t just mean 
someone like a manager or team leader or associate. It could be an intern or volunteer. It could 
be someone working part-time or full-time for the company. It can even be a consultant! The 
Act, meaning the law, places the responsibility of creating a safe workplace on anyone who 
works in any capacity for that workplace. 
 
4. What is “sexual harassment”?

4. What is “sexual harassment”? 
 
Sexual harassment is defined by the POSH Act in a very specific way. It is not restricted to 
physical touch. It does not need to be driven by bad or wrong intentions. It could be any 
behaviour of a sexual nature that makes another person, especially women, uncomfortable. It 
could be a personal question like “do you have a boyfriend?”. It could be a sexually coloured

compliment like “you look really sexy today” It could be WhatsApp messages about past sexual 
relationships. It could be double-meaning jokes about other co-workers. It could be singing 
item numbers from movies. It could be using slurs like MC or BC or regional language swear 
words.  
 
The law considers anything which is  
A. sexual and  
B. unwelcome  
as sexual harassment.  
If something is unwelcome, but not sexual, it is not sexual harassment. For example, a
colleague who throws paper balls at others may be engaging in unwelcome behaviour, but the

behaviour is not sexual. Unrealistic deadlines are unwelcome, but it could be work-related 
harassment. So, it is not sexual harassment.  
If something is sexual, but welcome (i.e., not unwelcome), it is not sexual harassment. For 
example,  if an organisation  allows  romantic  relationships,  there  could  be  welcome or 
consensual sexual relations between two employees. This is not sexual harassment.

Some examples of physical sexual harassment are: Touching inappropriately, Unwelcome hugs, 
Forced kissing, Standing too close, Long handshakes, Unwelcome touches 
Some examples of verbal sexual harassment are: Gossip about personal life of colleagues, 
Personal compliments, Sexual compliments, Comments of sexual nature, Jokes of sexual 
nature, Repeated proposals, Indirect requests for sex 
Some examples of non-verbal sexual harassment are: Staring, Winking, Whistling, Obscene

Gestures (like showing middle finger), Stalking, Online sexual conversations  
5. Who can complaint under the POSH law? Can men complain under the POSH law? 
 
A woman, whether employed with the organisation or not, can file a complaint under the 
POSH law. The woman can be an intern, volunteer, trainer, or a consultant visiting the 
organisation for work. If an organisation has a gender-neutral POSH policy, then people of

other genders can file a complaint with the Internal Committee of that organisation.  
 
6. Why is the law for women only? Why is the POSH law only for women? Why can only women 
complain under POSH? 
 
The POSH Act was enacted in 2013 – immediately after the Nirbhaya incident. So, the POSH 
Act is focused on women because of the historical and ongoing gender-based violence they 
face. India’s patriarchal social norms often make it difficult for them to enjoy long-term

employment. Sometimes, women  leave  their  jobs  when  they  face  sexual  harassment. 
Sometimes, their families discourage them from taking any legal action. This is why the law is 
for women.  
 
However, nowadays, many people believe India needs a gender-neutral law to protect 
everyone at work. Please refer to your organisation’s POSH policy to check if it is gender-
neutral. If it is, you may be able to file a complaint of sexual harassment.

7. Why was POSH law made? What is the history of the POSH Act? 
 
In 1992, Bhanwari Devi, a woman working as a social worker for the Rajasthan government, 
was gang-raped for trying to stop a child marriage. This showed how unsafe workplaces could 
be for women. In response, women's rights groups went to the Supreme Court under the name 
"Vishaka." The Court said that sexual harassment at work is a human rights issue and created

the Vishaka Guidelines to protect women. These rules had to be followed by all workplaces 
until a proper law was made. 
 
8. Can a cab ride count as workplace? What is a ‘workplace’ according to POSH Act? Will a phone 
call I make to my colleague count as a workplace? Are online interactions with colleagues 
viewed as ‘workplace’? Does social media count as ‘workplace’?

The term ‘workplace’ is defined very broadly under the POSH Act to ensure workplace safety 
in any potentially work-related scenario. This means that if an alleged act of sexual harassment 
takes place anywhere work-related, then the Internal Committee can look into the complaint. 
For example, workplace is not restricted to the four walls of an office. It could include the office 
parking lot, it could include work-related conferences, flights or train travel undertaken for

work, online video calls or phone calls made for work, and even chat platforms like WhatsApp, 
Instagram and Snapchat. As long as the interaction is between two colleagues, and likely to 
affect their working relationship, the interaction can be considered related to the workplace.  
 
The concept of an ‘extended workplace’ is crucial, meaning that even if an employee is not 
physically in the traditional workplace, their work-related activities and interactions, including

those at home or during business travel, can fall under the purview of the POSH Act.  
 
9. What is ‘Quid Pro Quo’? 
 
Quid pro quo is a Latin phrase meaning “this for that.” In the context of sexual harassment at 
the workplace, it refers to a situation where a person in a position of power (like a manager or 
team leader or supervisor) demands or implies that sexual favors are expected in exchange for 
workplace benefits. Quid pro quo sexual harassment occurs when:

Submission to sexual advances is made a condition for employment decisions. 
Work benefits such as hiring, promotion, salary hike, appraisal, favorable assignments, or 
continued employment are tied to accepting or rejecting sexual requests. 
 
For a sexual harassment to be considered as a ‘quid pro quo’ case, there has to be an unequal 
power dynamic between the parties involved. The person in a position of power is said to

misuse their power when they try to extract sexual favours in exchange for professional 
favours. Because of this, a “consensual” relationship between a senior and a junior can never 
be considered truly consensual in the eyes of the law.  
 
- If you go out with me, I’ll make sure you get the promotion. 
- Your project approval depends on how nice you are to me. 
- A manager subtly hints that not complying may lead to a poor performance review.

- A junior rejects a senior’s romantic proposal and the senior retaliates by withholding raises 
or assigning menial tasks or taunting and belittling the junior even though their rapport 
was good prior to the proposal 
- A manager subtly hints that other juniors have complied with sexual requests 
 
10. What is a Hostile Work Environment? 
 
Hostile Work Environment refers to a situation where an employee experiences unwelcome

conduct that creates an intimidating, offensive, or oppressive atmosphere at the workplace. 
While the POSH Act does not use the exact term "hostile work environment", it defines sexual 
harassment broadly to include behaviours that result in creating such an environment. This 
behaviour could include:  
- Sexually coloured remarks 
- Showing pornography

- Staring, leering, or suggestive gestures 
- Favouring other junior employees for being in a sexual relationship with a senior 
- Inappropriate jokes or comments (whether or not they are directed at the complainant) 
- Unwanted physical contact or advances 
- Uninvited romantic interest  
 
11. What does unwelcome mean? 
Unwelcome behaviour means that the behaviour is not invited by the receiver of the

behaviour. It is undesirable or unsolicited by the recipient, regardless of the intention of the 
person engaging in the behaviour.  
For example, if employee X tries to move towards employee Y to give employee X a hug, but X 
takes a few steps back away from Y, this should indicate to Y that X finds the hug unwelcome.  
If employee Y keeps asking X questions about past relationships, exes and sexual encounters

or virginity status, but X looks uncomfortable, doesn’t offer information or changes the topic, 
this should indicate to Y that X finds the questions unwelcome. 
Employee X may not always be able to indicate their discomfort. So, employee Y should take 
care to check if employee X is uncomfortable in any manner.  
 
12. Impact vs Intent 
 
Under the POSH Act, what matters most is the impact of the behaviour on the victim, not the 
intent of the person who did it. 
 
Even if the harasser says:

Even if the harasser says: 
 
“I was just joking!” 
“I didn’t mean to make that person uncomfortable.” 
“That’s how I talk with everyone.” 
 
...it does not excuse the behaviour if it made someone feel uncomfortable, humiliated, unsafe, 
or harassed. For the Internal Committee, intent is not the deciding factor in determining 
whether  behaviour  was sexual harassment. If  the  conduct  is  unwelcome  and  causes

discomfort or harm, it may be considered sexual harassment — even if the person “meant 
well.”  
 
For example, employee X may be a new joiner who is introverted and takes time to adjust to 
new situations and people. Employee Y may be extroverted and says to employee X, “Why are 
you so shy around the opposite gender? You’ve never been kissed or what?”. In this case, it is 
possible that the intention of Y was to make X feel included or joke around and build a rapport.

However, if it makes X feel uneasy, then the impact on them will be considered by the Internal 
Committee, not the (possibly) good intentions of Y.

Additional POSH FAQs – Basic Level
1. What is an Internal Committee (IC)?
An Internal Committee (IC), also known as the POSH Committee, is a body constituted by the employer to address complaints of sexual harassment
It must consist of a presiding officer (a senior woman employee), at least two members from amongst employees, and one external member from an NGO or similar organization with experience in handling harassment cases.
2. Who can be a member of the Internal Committee?

2. Who can be a member of the Internal Committee?
IC members must include a senior woman employee as the Presiding Officer, at least two other employees (preferably with one from the SC/ST or minority community), and one external expert
Members should not have any conflict of interest with the organization or its employees.
3. What is the tenure of IC members?
The tenure of IC members is three years from the date of appointment or until the completion of the inquiry, whichever is earlier

Members may be reappointed but their tenure should be specified in the company policy.
4. How do I file a complaint under the POSH Act?
A complaint can be filed by the aggrieved woman in writing (email, letter, or form) to the IC within 3 months from the date of the incident (extendable by another 3 months for valid reasons)
If the IC fails to act, a complaint can be made to the Local Complaints Committee.
5. What are the timelines for inquiry proceedings?

The IC must complete the inquiry within 90 days from receipt of the complaint
After completion, it must submit the report within 10 days to the employer for action
The employer must act on the recommendations within 60 days.
6. Can a complaint be filed after leaving the organisation?
Yes
An aggrieved woman can file a complaint within 90 days of the incident even if she has resigned or been terminated, provided the incident occurred during her tenure with the organization.

7. What is conciliation under the POSH Act?
Conciliation is an optional step where the IC may attempt to resolve the matter amicably before initiating formal inquiry, provided that no monetary settlement is made
Both parties must agree in writing to conciliation.
8. What interim relief can the IC recommend?

8. What interim relief can the IC recommend?
The IC may recommend interim relief such as transfer of the complainant or respondent, granting leave to the complainant, restricting the respondent from reporting to the complainant, or any other relief as deemed fit.
9. What are the employer's obligations under the POSH Act?

Employers must create and distribute a POSH policy, constitute the IC, organise annual awareness programs, provide necessary resources for the IC, preserve confidentiality, and ensure no retaliation against complainants.
10. What happens if an organisation fails to constitute an IC?
Failure to constitute an IC or comply with POSH provisions can result in penalties under the Act, including fines and cancellation of business licenses for repeated non-compliance.
